questions.text: A second year medical student attending his viva in the microbiology department, was asked to identify the given device and name any one item that can be sterilised by it. Which of the following options is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Hot air oven and culture media

questions.correct_answer: C. Hot air oven and glassware

questions.text: Match the following sterilisation techniques with their respective control methods. Sterilisation technique Control method 1. Hot air oven a. Bacillus pumilus 2. Autoclave b. Serratia marcescens 3. Membrane filtration c. Bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis spores 4.Ionizing Radiation d. Geobacillus stearothermophilus spores
questions.explanation:
Sterilisation technique

Control method

1. Hot air oven

c. Bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis spores

2. Autoclave

d. Geobacillus stearothermophilus spores

3. Membrane filtration

b. Serratia marcescens

4.Ionizing Radiation

a. Bacillus pumilus

questions.text: During a community health meeting, a health inspector discusses the importance of preventing consumption of raw milk from cattle. What is the false statement regarding the treatment process of raw milk before consumption?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a type of disinfection method that uses moist heat.

options.label: B
options.text: Holder method is used to disinfect milk from Coxiella burnetii.

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of the enzyme phosphatase in the milk post-treatment suggests inadequate efficacy.

options.label: D
options.text: It helps to extend the shelf life of milk.

questions.correct_answer: B. Holder method is used to disinfect milk from Coxiella burnetii.
questions.explanation:
Below 100°

At 100°

Above 100°

Inspisissation

Boiling

Autoclave

Pasteurization

Tyndallization

  

Vaccine water bath

questions.text: Which of the following sterilisation/disinfection techniques acts on the principle of moist heat at 100 o C?

As an intern in the orthopaedic department, you have been tasked to deliver the surgical instruments planned for the operating theatre to the CSSD. What temperature settings are kept in the following sterilisation machine at the CSSD? CSSD - Central Sterile Supply Department

options.label: A
options.text: 121 o C for 15 minutes at 15 psi pressure

options.label: D
options.text: 80 o C for 20-30 minutes for 3 consecutive days

questions.correct_answer: A. 121 o C for 15 minutes at 15 psi pressure

questions.text: Which of the following substances can be sterilised by membrane filters?
questions.explanation:
Air filtration

Water filtration

  • It is done by using high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters designed to remove organisms larger than 0.3 μm from isolation rooms, operating rooms, and biological safety cabinets (BSCs).
  • ULPA filters (Ultra-low particulate/penetration air) can remove from the air at least 99.9% of dust and any airborne particles with a size of 0.12 μm or larger.
  • Surgical (3-ply) masks and respirators are the simplest examples of filters being used for purification of air. They remove microorganisms based on their pore size.
  • Used for bacteriological examination of water in hospital settings, especially dialysis water.
  • Also used to remove bacteria from pharmaceutical fluids that are heat labile and cannot be purified by any other means e.g. sera, sugar, toxin, vaccine and antibiotic solutions.

questions.text: What is the quality control agent used in the shown method of disinfection?
questions.explanation:
Ionising

Features:

  • High penetration power
  • Sporicidal action +
  • Known as Cold radiation (do not increase surface heat)
  • Examples: Gamma rays, X-rays, Cosmic rays

Uses:

  • Plastics, syringes, catheters
  • Catgut sutures - Gamma (γ) rays

Non-ionising

Features:

  • Low penetration power
  • Only bactericidal action +
  • Examples: UV rays, infrared rays

Uses:

  • Plastics, syringes, catheters

Mechanism of action
  • DNA damage by Dimer formation

Quality control agent

  • Bacillus pumilus (Option C)

questions.text: What is the ideal agent of choice for sterilizing the shown instrument?
questions.explanation:
Risk category

Recommended method

Medical device/Equipment

1. Critical device (high risk): Items that enter a normally sterile site.

Sterilisation

  • If heat resistant: Hot air oven or autoclave
  • If heat-sensitive: Ionising radiation or ethylene oxide or plasma sterilisation.

Surgical instruments, implants/prostheses, rigid endoscopes, syringes, needles, CuT, Urinary catheter

2. Semi-critical device (intermediate risk):

Items in contact with mucous membranes or body fluids.

High-level disinfection (HLD):

Such as glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde, formaldehyde and hydrogen peroxide.

Respiratory equipment, non-invasive flexible endoscopes, bedpans, urine bottles

3. Non-critical (low-risk)

Items in contact with intact skin.

Intermediate or Low-level disinfection (ILD or LLD):

Such as phenols, chlorhexidine, isopropyl alcohol, povidone-iodine, etc

Patient items include blood pressure cuffs, ECG electrodes, thermometer and stethoscopes.

 

Environmental surfaces include computers, bed rails, food utensils, bedside tables, patient furniture and floor.

Examples
  • 2% Glutaraldehyde (Option A): Activated by alkalinisation
  • 0.55% Orthophthaldehyde: More stable, more active
  • Formaldehyde

Mechanism of action
  • Alkylation + DNA damage by cross linking

Uses [Semi-critical: in contact with mucous membrane]
  • Flexible endoscopes, Laryngoscope (Option A), Vaginal speculum, Anesthetic equipment.
  • Specific uses:
    • Formaldehyde: OT fumigation
    • Glutaraldehyde: Bronchoscopes and laryngoscopes
    • Orthophthaldehyde: Cystoscopes

Examples
  • 70% Ethyl alcohol (spirit), Isopropyl alcohol, Methyl alcohol

Mechanism of action
  • Membrane damage + denaturation of bacterial proteins

Uses [Non-critical: in contact with intact skin]
  • Skin antiseptic, Thermometers, Stethoscopes
  • Methyl alcohol: Fungal spores, incubators

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the most commonly used oral antiseptic?
questions.explanation:
Examples
  • Cresol: Rideal-walker coefficient- 10, Stools disinfectant
  • Lysol: Hospital disinfectant
  • Chloroxylenol: Less action against Pseudomonas
  • Chlorhexidine: non-toxic

Mechanism of action
  • Membrane damage + Protein denaturation (Option D)

Uses

  • Skin antiseptics, wound dressing
  • Hospital floors and surroundings disinfectant
  • Chlorhexidine: Oral antiseptic

Examples
  • Tincture Iodine (2% Iodine): bactericidal + sporicidal
  • Povidone Iodine (Betadine): has residual action
  • Sodium hypochlorite (5.25%): Both bactericidal + virucidal

Mechanism of action
  • Oxidisation (Option A)

Uses

  • Skin antiseptic, wound dressing (Betadine preferred)
  • Town water supply, Swimming pools (Chlorine)
  • Sodium hypochlorite: Blood spills (1:10/1:100 dilution of 5.25% solution used)

questions.text: Which among the following is NOT true regarding Gas sterilisation?

options.label: A
options.text: Mechanism of bactericidal action is Alkylation

options.label: C
options.text: Refers to Ethylene oxide ideally used at 55-60°C for 4-12 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Suitable for fumigation of OT complexes

questions.correct_answer: D. Suitable for fumigation of OT complexes
questions.explanation:
Most commonly used
  • Ethylene oxide (ETO)

Concentration
  • 450-700 mg ETO at 55-60°C for 4-12 hours (Option C)

Mechanism of action
  • Alkylation of DNA (Option A) and associated microbial proteins

Uses
  • Cardio-pulmonary (Heart-Lung) machine (Option B), Respirators [Critical class under Spaulding’s classification]

Disadvantages
  • Irritant: workers must use protective wears while using
  • Explosive & Inflammable: Not suitable for fumigation (Option D)

questions.text: What is the ideal agent of choice for managing blood spill from a fall of 5 mL vacutainer?
Which among the following tests gives a real-time assessment of microbiological contamination of a disinfectant in use?
questions.explanation:
Rideal-Walker test
  • Also known as the Phenol coefficient test.
  • Tests the efficacy of a phenolic disinfectants (Lysol, Cresol) to kill Salmonella Typhi.
  • Coefficient > 1 signifies that the disinfectant is efficacious.
  • Disadvantage: Efficacy of organic matter is unknown

Chick Martin test
  • Modification of the Rideal-Walker test
  • Tests the efficacy of phenolic disinfectant in presence of organic matter.

Kelsey-Sykes test
  • Tests the capacity of disinfectant to retain its activity with increasing microbiological load when used repeatedly.

Kelsey-Maurer test
  • Real-time assessment of microbiological contamination of in-use disinfectants in hospital

questions.text: A chronic smoker with persistent cough was found to have a lung mass on imaging. A bronchoscope was used to obtain a lung biopsy. Based on the Spaulding classification, what category does this medical device fall under, and what is the appropriate sterilisation or disinfection agent?
questions.explanation:
Risk category

Recommended method

Medical device/Equipment

1. Critical device (high risk): Items that enter a normally sterile site.

Sterilisation

  • If heat resistant: Hot air oven or autoclave
  • If heat sensitive: Ionising radiation or ethylene oxide or plasma sterilisation.

Surgical instruments, implants/prosthesis, rigid endoscopes, syringes, needles, CuT, Urinary catheter

2. Semi-critical device (intermediate risk):

Items in contact with mucous membranes or body fluids.

High-level disinfection (HLD):

such as glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde, formaldehyde and hydrogen peroxide.

Respiratory equipment, non-invasive flexible endoscopes, bedpans, urine bottles

3. Non-critical (low-risk)

Items in contact with intact skin.

Intermediate or Low-level disinfection (ILD or LLD):

Such as phenols, chlorhexidine, isopropyl alcohol, povidone iodine, etc

Patient items include blood pressure cuffs, ECG electrodes, thermometers and stethoscopes.

 

Environmental surfaces include computers, bed rails, food utensils, bedside tables, patient furniture and floor.

questions.text: To which group of disinfectants does the commonly used cetrimide solution belong to?
